title: Installation
content: This library provides a wide range of tools for automating and simplifying your Angular applications. It also offers declarative approaches to solving common development problems, helping you maintain a consistent codebase across multiple projects and making developer migration between them easier.

title: Directives
content: Here is a list of directives that can be useful for working in applications using @angular/ssr

title: Directives
content: Renders template content only in the browser. If the application is running on the server, the content will not be displayed. This is useful for performing DOM manipulations and using third-party libraries that only work in the browser.

title: Directives
content: In client-side rendering, the main work of creating the HTML page is performed on the client side (in the browser) using JavaScript.

title: Directives
content: These examples show that such code will only work in the client environment. DOM manipulations and connecting third-party libraries, for example, for creating charts and animations, will only work in the browser. This prevents code execution on the server, which can lead to errors.

title: Directives
content: If your application supports SSR, don't forget to check during local development that there are no errors.

title: Directives
content: Renders template content only on the server. This is useful for preloading data and displaying it on the page before the page is loaded in the browser.

title: Directives
content: In server-side rendering, the HTML page is fully generated on the server and sent to the client. This provides fast initial page loading and better SEO optimization.

title: Directives
content: On the server, you can preload data and display it on the page before the page is loaded in the browser. This allows you to speed up page loading and improve user experience, especially with slow connections.

title: Directives
content: If your application supports SSR, don't forget to check during local development that there are no errors.

title: Cookies
content: This module provides the ability to work with document cookies via a dedicated service. The implementation also supports working with cookies in ssr applications, helping to avoid errors in different runtime environments.

title: Cookies

title: Cookies
content: Service for working with cookies. It provides a convenient interface for handling cookies both in the browser and on SSR. It abstracts the differences between client and SSR environments, allowing you to work with cookies in a unified way regardless of the execution context (in SSR only has, get, and getAll are available, other actions are stubbed). If cookies are disabled in the browser, the service switches to stub mode, where all operations result in logging to the console.

title: Decorators
content: This module provides a small set of typescript decorators for simplifying and optimizing your codebase.

title: Decorators
content: Automatically binds a method to the class instance context, ensuring that this always refers to the correct object.

title: Decorators
content: Used when you need to replace the context. By default, always executes in the context of the class instance.

title: Decorators
content: In this example, the context inside the map pipe is lost because the pipe calls the method without explicitly binding the context to the original class. The @Bind decorator solves this problem by ensuring the method is always called with the correct context.

title: Decorators
content: Used for caching the results of a method execution.

title: Decorators
content: Whether to clear cached results after the component or service's

title: Decorators
content: In this example, you need to generate a QR code for a payment based on its type. This operation is computationally expensive. Since the number of payment types is limited, you can use this decorator so that the QR code is generated only once for each payment type. On subsequent calls, the decorator checks if it has already created a QR code for this payment type and returns the cached result, skipping repeated calculations.

title: Decorators
content: Allows you to subscribe to changes of input parameters in a component. When the keys specified in the decorator change, the decorated method is called. Works for fields declared via @Input and for InputSignal. Based on the ngOnChanges lifecycle hook and serialization of the SimpleChanges object.

title: Decorators
content: Names of input fields to watch. If a string is passed, the function is called with the field value as the first parameter. If an array is passed, an object with key-value pairs is returned as the first parameter.

title: Decorators
content: In the onInputIdChange method (*1), we watch for changes to the id field. Each time this input parameter changes externally, the method is called with the updated value as the first parameter.In the onInputMultiChange method (*2), we watch for changes to two fields: name and age. Each time either input parameter changes externally, the method is called with the updated values as an object with name and age fields. Note that even if only one parameter changes, the method receives an object with the new value for the changed parameter and the current value for the unchanged parameter.

title: Decorators
content: Allows you to subscribe to the OnInit lifecycle hook. All methods using this decorator will be executed immediately after ngOnInit is called in the component. This avoids declaring the ngOnInit hook for typical and repetitive methods.

title: Decorators
content: In this example, the methodTwo and methodThree methods will be called immediately after ngOnInit;

title: Decorators
content: When using the decorator, declaring the OnInit hook is optional.

title: Decorators
content: Allows you to subscribe to the OnDestroy lifecycle hook. All methods using this decorator will be executed immediately after ngOnDestroy is called in the component or service. This avoids declaring the ngOnDestroy hook for typical and repetitive methods.

title: Decorators
content: In this example, the methodTwo and methodThree methods will be called immediately after ngOnDestroy;

title: Decorators
content: When using the decorator, declaring the OnDestroy hook is optional.

title: useCache
content: A distinctive feature of the CacheRequest type is the presence of the cache method. The principle of this method is simple:

title: useCache
content: Make only one server request for data and then share it with all other consumers

title: useCache
content: You can become a data consumer by calling the cache method. The single request for data will be made when the first subscriber uses the cache method. All others will wait for the request result and receive the data in the value field. The loading status will also be available in the loading field.

title: useCache
content: A simple example where this method is relevant:

title: useCache
content: A request for country codes for phone numbers used in form elements. You need to get the data only once and only if a component that uses them is rendered. There may be several components with such forms. To avoid writing logic that checks for an already executed request and received data, you can use the cache method.

title: useCache
content: method of this request in consumer components.

title: useCache
content: If needed, you can skip the config field with the request name and do this via direct call hub.countryCodes$.cache()

title: useCache
content: The first rendered consumer component will make the request for data, all others will receive the result of the executed request in the value field.

title: useCache
content: You can get the status of loaded data via the loaded field. The property is mutable. This means you can load data externally by changing the value field and setting loaded to true. In this case, the request will not be made, and consumer components will receive the current value.

title: useCache
content: The loaded status is also affected by calling the setUrlOptions method with the withRequest field. It also sets loaded to true upon successful execution.

title: useCache
content: The reset method sets loaded to false. This means the request will be made again by the next consumer component.

title: useCache
content: Calling the setUrlOptions method without the withRequest field will set options for the first request. This is useful when the url uses parameters that need to be set for the request if a consumer component is rendered.

title: useCache
content: To update data, you can also use the send method.

If no value is set, the key for this value is ignored and does not get into the class instance during creation. This feature is dictated by the TypeScript language.

title: Introduction

title: Introduction

title: Introduction

title: Introduction
content: For describing the configuration file loading process in this block, we use the withEnvironment strategy, since most projects use it. However, the preferred loading strategy now is withInitializeState. Its usage is also described in the section From Angular 18 and above.

title: Introduction
content: In projects, when deploying to test or live environments, you often need configuration files with certain data that should differ depending on the environment. We store these in a data.json file located at src/assets/config/ from the Angular project root.

title: Introduction
content: When deploying to different environments (live, test, dev, etc.), the contents of data.json may be updated and have its own set of values for each environment.

title: Introduction
content: In Angular projects, it's canonical to create an environments directory at src/environments from the project root. This directory often contains 2 environment files for dev and prod modes: environment.ts and environment.prod.ts. The environment.prod.ts file is optional but can be used to replace environment.ts during production builds using fileReplacements.

title: Introduction
content: For provideUtilsInitializer, it's recommended to create a subdirectory interfaces in src/environments with a file describing the environment variables interface, which will be present in environment.ts at runtime. This interface should extend InitializeMeta, which contains the required CONFIG_ROOT field for the path to data.json. This is needed for provideUtilsInitializer.

title: Introduction
content: The final environments directory may look like this:

title: Introduction
content: Note that API_HOST and WS_HOST are optional and are fields from data.json. They will be added to the environment object in environment.ts by the provider, but you don't need to declare them initially. This is for convenience, as the list of fields may be large, and only required fields need default values. If the list is small or you prefer stricter typing, you can make the fields required.

title: Introduction
content: Next, just inject the provideUtilsInitializer dependency in your application's root config with the withEnvironment strategy:

title: Introduction
content: When the application starts, the provider will request data.json at the path in CONFIG_ROOT and merge (mutate environment) the two objects. After that, you can use environment variables directly from the environment object in environment.ts.

title: Introduction
content: You can organize data.json storage any way you like. The main thing is that the file is present in your project's build directory when deploying to test or live environments, and environment files contain correct paths in CONFIG_ROOT.

title: Introduction
content: Changes in angular.json should include the assets directory in the build for production mode and replace environment files.

title: Introduction
content: Injecting the provider in Angular 18 and above assumes the default public directory for static files.

title: BrowserStorage
content: Configuration parameters BrowserStorageConfig used in methods override the default behavior set at the application level in the config parameter of the provideBrowserStorage provider. By default, the strategy field is set to json, meaning all write/read methods (get, set, patch) in the service will use JSON.stringify/JSON.parse respectively. This allows you to preserve the original data type when working with storage. It is not recommended to override this strategy.

title: BrowserStorage
content: If the user has blocked web storage usage via browser settings, the BrowserStorage service will create a stub object for reading/writing data. This prevents breaking the main logic of your applications in such cases. However, keep in mind that if the page is reloaded, closed, and reopened, the stub object will be recreated each time. If storing data in web storage is critical for your logic, you can use the check method or function (isEnabledBrowserStorage) to determine storage availability before reading/writing.

title: Style Guides
content: This guide describes the main rules for writing code in SPA applications. It helps keep most of the company's project codebases in a unified style, making developer migration between projects easier and reducing routine questions.

title: Style Guides
content: All pages must be stored in the ./pages folder

title: Style Guides
content: 1.1 All root pages must be stored at ./src/app/pages

title: Style Guides
content: 1.2 All internal pages (routes) used in the parent route template must be stored at ./{parent-page}/pages/{child-page}

title: Style Guides
content: A page is a component that has its own path in the routing tree

title: Style Guides
content: All child components used in the parent component template must be stored in the ./components folder

title: Style Guides
content: All internal pages (routes) must repeat the file structure of the root directory of the parent route.

title: Style Guides
content: All shared types, services, models, etc. for components and child routes must be stored in the root directory of the parent route

title: Style Guides
content: Each page, if necessary, must have an index.ts file in the root directory, exporting elements needed by other pages

title: Style Guides
content: Example of a correct structure for the documents page with child pages (routes) agreement, maf, nda:

title: Style Guides
content: Modules must be stored in the ./modules folder

title: Style Guides
content: The module name must include the parent component name

title: Style Guides
content: 4.1 .src/core directory if the module is used throughout the application

title: Style Guides
content: 4.2 ./modules directory of the parent page (route) if the module is used within the page and its descendants

title: Style Guides
content: Module creation may be based on the following rules:

title: Style Guides
content: 5.1 The module must have its own component, not being a separate page

title: Style Guides
content: 5.2 The module must have an API connection

title: Style Guides
content: 5.3 The module may be used in one or more places in the application, isolating functionality not directly related to the usage context

title: Style Guides
content: The module must repeat the folder and file structure presented in this guide

title: Style Guides
content: If the module exports services, a provide function must be implemented in ./providers/index.ts. Example:

title: Style Guides
content: The module's root directory must have an ./index.ts file exporting all public elements of the module

title: Style Guides
content: Example of a weather module used in app.component:

title: Style Guides
content: All features must be stored in the ./features folder

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {PascalCase}Feature pattern for exported feature service class names

content: 4.1 .src/core directory if the feature is used throughout the application

title: Style Guides
content: 4.2 ./features directory of the parent page (route) if the feature is used within the page and its descendants

title: Style Guides
content: Feature creation may be based on the following rules:

title: Style Guides
content: 5.1 The feature SHOULD NOT have its own component

title: Style Guides
content: 5.2 The feature may/should (depending on context) have an API connection

title: Style Guides
content: 5.3 The feature may be used in one or more places in the application

title: Style Guides
content: Most often, feature functionality is implemented in one or more services

title: Style Guides
content: The feature must repeat the folder and file structure presented in this guide

title: Style Guides
content: To export services, a provide function must be implemented in ./providers/index.ts. Example:

title: Style Guides
content: The feature's root directory must have an ./index.ts file exporting all public elements

title: Style Guides
content: Example of a websocket module initialized in app.component:

title: Style Guides
content: All components must be stored in the ./components folder

title: Style Guides
content: If the component decorator's imports or providers field has more than 2 imported entities, move them to ./imports/index.ts

title: Style Guides
content: Use {PascalCase}Imports and {PascalCase}Providers for naming imports and providers arrays:

title: Style Guides
content: All component fields used in the template must have the protected access modifier, unless referenced via viewChild, contentChild, etc.

title: Style Guides
content: All fields not used in the template must have the private access modifier, unless used in inheritance.

title: Style Guides
content: All nested components must be in the ./components folder of the parent component and always have an identical folder structure.

title: Style Guides
content: Example of a correct structure for the ./components/modal-popup component:

title: Style Guides
content: The routes file must be stored in the ./routes folder

title: Style Guides
content: The ./routes folder must be in the root of the parent component of this route

title: Style Guides
content: The file name must be index.ts

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {PascalCase}Routes pattern for naming the routes array

title: Style Guides
content: If more than 2 services are registered in the providers field of a route, they must be placed in a constant named {PascalCase}RouteProviders in the current routes file

title: Style Guides
content: All children fields in the route object must be imported arrays from the directories of their root modules.

title: Style Guides
content: All child routes must repeat the identical structure

title: Style Guides
content: All interfaces must be stored in the ./interfaces folder

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {kebab-case}.interface.ts pattern for file naming

title: Style Guides
content: Use the I{PascalCase} pattern for interface naming

title: Style Guides
content: Interface storage levels are determined by component nesting levels:

title: Style Guides
content: 4.1 If the interface is used in parallel components, it must be stored in the root of the parent component.

title: Style Guides
content: 4.2 If the interface is used only in the component and/or its descendants, it must be stored in the root of that component

title: Style Guides
content: Creating an interface is justified in the following cases:

title: Style Guides
content: 5.1 If the described data is received or sent via API

title: Style Guides
content: 5.2 If the interface is implemented by multiple entities such as Classes or Models

title: Style Guides
content: 5.3 If the interface describes the functionality of any InjectionToken (directive, component, pipe, service, etc.)

title: Style Guides
content: The interface declaration must always be at the top of the file. Related parts such as enums, types, etc. must be placed below the parent interface declaration. This allows you to focus on the main entity when opening the file.

title: Style Guides
content: Type files must be stored in the ./types folder

title: Style Guides
content: File naming must follow these rules:

title: Style Guides
content: 2.1 If there is only one file - index.ts

title: Style Guides
content: Use the T{PascalCase} pattern for type naming

title: Style Guides
content: 4.1 If the type is used only in the component and its descendants, it must be stored within its component.

title: Style Guides
content: 4.2 If the type is used in parallel components, it must be stored within the parent component.

title: Style Guides
content: 4.3 If the type relates only to an entity such as Classes, Models, Interfaces, States, it must be stored in the file of its entity

title: Style Guides
content: Types SHOULD NOT be used when interacting with API (in most cases)

title: Style Guides
content: Enum files must be stored in the ./enums folder

title: Style Guides
content: File naming must follow these rules:

title: Style Guides
content: 2.1 If there is only one file - index.ts

title: Style Guides
content: 3.1 If the enum is used only in the component and its descendants, it must be stored within its component.

title: Style Guides
content: 3.2 If the enum is used in parallel components, it must be stored within their parent component.

title: Style Guides
content: 3.3 If the enum relates only to an entity such as Classes, Models, Interfaces, States, it must be stored in the file of its entity

title: Style Guides
content: All enums must be declared using const

title: Style Guides
content: All enum fields must use the SNAKE_UPPER_CASE notation

title: Style Guides
content: Use the En{PascalCase} pattern for enum naming

title: Style Guides
content: Class files must be stored in the ./classes folder

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {kebab-case}.class.ts pattern for file naming

title: Style Guides
content: Use the PascalCase pattern for class naming

title: Style Guides
content: 4.1 If the class is used only in the component and its descendants, it must be stored within its component.

title: Style Guides
content: 4.2 If the class is used in parallel components, it must be stored within their parent component.

title: Style Guides
content: The class declaration must always be at the top of the file. Related parts such as enums, types, etc. must be placed below the parent class declaration.

title: Style Guides
content: Creating a class is justified in the following cases:

title: Style Guides
content: 6.1 If the class implements logic for working with, storing, mapping, managing, etc. various data (for example, hides the implementation for working with step-by-step form data)

title: Style Guides
content: 6.2 If the class isolates a certain set of semantically related functionality (for example, implements a set of methods for form validation)

title: Style Guides
content: Model files must be stored in the ./models folder

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {kebab-case}.model.ts pattern for file naming

title: Style Guides
content: Use the PascalCase pattern for class naming

title: Style Guides
content: 4.1 If the model is used only in the component and its descendants, it must be stored within its component.

title: Style Guides
content: 4.2 If the model is used in parallel components, it must be stored within their parent component.

title: Style Guides
content: The model declaration must always be at the top of the file. Related parts such as enums, types, etc. must be placed below the parent model declaration.

title: Style Guides
content: Creating a model is justified in the following cases:

title: Style Guides
content: 6.1 If the described data is received or sent via API, but minimal logic is required when preparing the data (for example, modifying incoming values when creating a class instance, using default values)

title: Style Guides
content: 6.2 If the described data requires the same conditions as in point 4.1, without API binding (for example, a getter method that transforms stored model data into the required format)

title: Style Guides
content: For working with API use the @ngmd/utils/http module

title: Style Guides
content: ApiHub must be stored in the ./api folder

title: Style Guides
content: ApiHub file naming must follow these rules:

title: Style Guides
content: 3.1 If there is only one file - index.ts

title: Style Guides
content: The ApiHub class name must follow the {PascalCase}ApiHub pattern:

title: Style Guides
content: The ApiHub variable name when used in a component must follow the {camelCase}Hub$ pattern:

title: Style Guides
content: When creating a request, the variable name must follow the final notation:

title: Style Guides
content: For creating urlOptions parameters always use the UrlOptions type

title: Style Guides
content: 8.1 In components if these types are not exported

title: Style Guides
content: 8.2 In the ApiHub file under the class definition, in the ./types/index.ts folder if types are exported

title: Style Guides
content: The service file must be stored in the ./services folder

title: Style Guides
content: File naming must follow these rules:

title: Style Guides
content: 2.1 If there is only one file - index.ts

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {PascalCase}Service pattern for class naming

title: Style Guides
content: The following entities may have a service:

title: Style Guides
content: 5.1 If the service is used in the component and its descendants, it must be stored within its component.

title: Style Guides
content: 5.2 If the service is used in parallel components, it must be stored within their parent component.

title: Style Guides
content: 5.3 If the service is used in entities other than a component, it must be stored in the root directory of its entity

title: Style Guides
content: Service may have its own set of Actions

title: Style Guides
content: 7.1 Providing communication between parent and child components via shared states and methods

title: Style Guides
content: 7.2 Implementing API request logic and handling

title: Style Guides
content: 7.2 Isolating contextual logic within the entity to which the service belongs

title: Style Guides
content: All child entities may inject the parent entity's service

title: Style Guides
content: To return the service to its default state, depending on context, use the ngOnDestroy or destroy methods

content: For working with state use the @ngmd/utils/state module

title: Style Guides
content: The state file must be stored at ./state

title: Style Guides
content: File naming must follow these rules: 3.1 If there is only one file - index.ts 3.2 If more than one file - {kebab-case}.state.ts

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {PascalCase}State pattern for class naming

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {camelCase}State pattern for field naming in the component

title: Style Guides
content: Example of a correctly created state file:

title: Style Guides
content: For working with events use the @ngmd/utils/actions module

title: Style Guides
content: The events file must be stored in the ./actions folder

title: Style Guides
content: File naming must follow these rules: 3.1 If there is only one file - either index.ts 3.2 If more than one file - {kebab-case}.actions.ts

title: Style Guides
content: Use the T{PascalCase}Actions pattern for event list type naming

title: Style Guides
content: Use the kebab-case pattern for event string type naming

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {SNAKE_CASE}_ACTIONS pattern for event access token naming

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {camelCase}Actions$ pattern for variable naming in the component

content: Example of a correctly created event list file:

title: Style Guides
content: For working with storage use the @ngmd/utils/store module

title: Style Guides
content: The storage file must be stored in the ./store folder

title: Style Guides
content: File naming must follow these rules: 3.1 If there is only one file - index.ts 3.2 If more than one file - {kebab-case}.store.ts

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {PascalCase}Store pattern for class naming

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {camelCase}Store pattern for field naming in the component

title: Style Guides
content: Store may only be used for storing data received via API

title: Style Guides
content: Example of a correctly created storage file:

title: Style Guides
content: For working with static data use the @ngmd/utils/db module

title: Style Guides
content: The data file must be stored at ./db

title: Style Guides
content: File naming must follow these rules: 3.1 If there is only one file - index.ts 3.2 If more than one file - {kebab-case}.db.ts

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {PascalCase}DB pattern for object naming

title: Style Guides
content: All static data used in the business logic of the application must be stored in db

title: Style Guides
content: For naming keys with data related to a specific component, it is preferable to create a key with the component name and a value as an object containing only that component's data

title: Style Guides
content: Example of correct static data storage:

title: Style Guides
content: The constants file must be stored in the ./constants folder

title: Style Guides
content: File naming must follow these rules:

title: Style Guides
content: 2.1 If there is only one file - index.ts

title: Style Guides
content: Use the {SNAKE_UPPER_CASE} pattern for constant naming

title: Style Guides
content: For storing technical or strict constant values in libraries or applications, it is allowed to use constants if values need to be isolated from storage in DB or Enums.

title: Style Guides
content: The handlers file must be stored in the ./handlers folder

title: Style Guides
content: File naming must follow these rules:

title: Style Guides
content: 2.1 If there is only one file - either index.ts

title: Style Guides
content: For isolating certain logic, it is also allowed to create and use helper functions that implement routine repetitive logic in many parts of the application.

title: Style Guides
content: For choosing storage, follow these rules: 4.1 If the function is used throughout the application, it should be stored at ./app/core/handlers/index.ts. If there are many helpers, you can use contextual naming: string.handlers.ts, condition.handlers.ts, etc. In this case, index.ts will re-export the functionality of these files.

title: Style Guides
content: 4.2 If the function is used only in a specific entity and/or its descendants, it should be stored in the root directory of its entity

content: Example of the handlers directory for the entire application ./app/core/handlers:

content: And functionality in the example file string.handlers.ts:

title: Style Guides
content: For storing the most common parts of the application (components, pipes, directives, etc.), use the ./app/core directory with the alias tag @core specified in the paths field of tsconfig.json. Each module must also have an index.ts file exporting the necessary entities.

content: Have an exported provide function for injection into consumer applications (e.g. provideSomeLibrary())

title: Style Guides
content: Export only functionality intended for external use

title: Directives
content: This module provides a set of Angular directives for solving a range of common problems.

title: Directives
content: Designed to track user activity and emit an event if the user does not perform any actions (mouse movement or click, keyboard press, touch on touchscreens) within a specified time.

title: Directives
content: Delay in milliseconds after which the inactivity event is triggered if no user actions are detected.

title: Directives
content: Number of times the inactivity event can be triggered. By default, there is practically no limit.

title: Directives
content: , the directive will not track user actions.

title: Directives
content: Event emitted when there is no user activity for the specified time in the

title: Directives
content: Allows you to declaratively set a background image for an element.

title: Directives
content: Designed to determine whether the user clicked inside a given element or its child elements, based on CSS selectors. Useful for implementing functionality like clicking outside an element to close a modal or dropdown.

title: Directives
content: CSS selectors that define elements to check if a click occurred inside them. Can be a single selector string or an array of selectors.

title: Directives
content: Event emitted on every click. Returns true if the click occurred inside one of the specified selectors, false otherwise.

title: Directives
content: The emitHandler will receive true if you click inside the my-component or inside the parent div with the class parent or my-class.

title: Directives
content: Designed to copy text to the clipboard when clicking on the element to which the directive is applied.

title: Directives
content: Text to copy to the clipboard.

title: Directives
content: Designed for programmatically managing the focus of an element. Allows you to dynamically set or remove focus from an element.

title: Directives
content: Boolean value that controls the focus of the element. If

title: Directives
content: or not set, focus is set on the element. If

title: Directives

title: Directives
content: Designed for dynamically inserting DOM elements into specified places on the page. It takes two input parameters: the insertion position and the target element selector.

title: Directives
content: Defines the position where the element should be inserted relative to the target element. Accepts:

title: Directives
content: (inside the target element, before all content),

title: Directives
content: (inside the target element, after all content),

title: Directives
content: CSS selector of the target element. This value specifies which DOM element the insertion operation applies to. The element defined by this selector serves as the reference point for insertion.

title: Directives
content: Designed to track when an element appears in the viewport. It uses IntersectionObserver to determine when the element to which the directive is applied crosses a specified visibility threshold. Useful for implementing lazy loading, appearance animations, and other actions depending on whether the user sees the element on the screen.

title: Directives
content: CSS selector of the element used as the viewport for checking visibility of the target element. Should be an ancestor of the target element.

title: Directives
content: The directive will trigger change detection every time the element crosses the visibility threshold.

title: Directives
content: Sets margins around the root element, changing the size of the area for intersection checking. Can have values like the CSS margin property: "10px 20px 30px 40px" - (top, right, bottom, left). Values can be set in percentages. Defaults to zero for all parameters.

title: Directives
content: Number (from 0 to 1) indicating at what percentage of the target element's visibility the event should be triggered. For example, if set to 0.5, the event will be emitted when 50% of the element's area is visible in the viewport.

title: Directives
content: Event triggered every time the element enters or leaves the specified visibility threshold. Provides an array of IntersectionObserverEntry objects containing intersection state information.

title: Directives
content: Designed to provide navigation to a URL specified as a parameter. The directive tracks user clicks on the element to which it is applied and navigates to the specified URL.

title: Directives
content: URL to navigate to when the element is clicked.

title: Directives
content: Designed to track when the user scrolls the page or element to certain boundaries, such as bottom, top, left, or right.

title: Directives
content: List of boundaries to track, allowed values: `'bottom'

content: Specifies whether to track boundaries of the entire page or a specific element. If

content: Track scroll of this div to top and bottom. When the scroll reaches the top, the emit callback will send 'top', when it reaches the bottom, it will send 'bottom'.

title: Directives
content: Designed to apply styles to an element selected by a CSS selector.
